newsitem.title: USA: Semiconductor stocks firm after book-to-bill rise.
newsitem.headline: Semiconductor stocks firm after book-to-bill rise.

text.p: Shares of the U.S. computer chipmakers received a modest boost after the industry reported its book-to-bill ratio firmed in August, despite warnings of a profits shortfall from Motorola Inc.

Shares of microprocessor giant Intel Corp hit a 52-week high of 84-7/8 and was trading up 5/16 at 84-5/8 at midsession, while Micron Technology Inc, the Idaho-based memory chip maker, jumped 1-1/8 to 22.
Intel was the second most actively traded share on the Nasdaq market. Motorola, which said third-quarter earnings may be significantly below its second quarter, fell 1-5/8 to 49.
The Semiconductor Industry Association said after the market close on Tuesday the industry's book-to-bill ratio rose to 0.90 in August from a revised July ratio of 0.86.

The index means that for every $100 in shipments last month, semiconductor firms received $90 in new orders. An index above 1.00 normally means demand for computer chips is expanding while a ratio below one means demand is slowing.

Industry analysts had expected the ratio to be between 0.86 and 0.92. Many analysts said the number was a positive sign, since new orders rose fractionally on a sequential basis in a summer month when demand is usually slack.
"Other companies that may struggle in Q3 include VLSI, Texas Instruments, Novellus Systems, Lam Research and Applied Materials," Klauer said.
VLSI Technology rose 5/16 at 13-1/16, Texas Instruments edged 1/8 higher to 45-5/8, Novellus Systems Inc rose 1/4 to 36, Lam rose 1/8 to 23-1/2 and Applied Materials rose 5/16 3/8 to 23-5/8.

Although the monthly book-to-bill figure is a key industry indicator, many analysts and companies are critical that it only covers the America region, rather than the global market, and is a broad measure across all semiconductor products.

"Our business is fundamentally microprocessors but book-to-bill is broader from a product point of view," an Intel spokesman said. "It's too broad for us from a product point of view and too narrow from a geographic standpoint."
The Intel spokesman declined to discus the company's third quarter financial performance in detail, but said the company has not changed its perspective on the overall market.
"We have said that we generally see a robust PC market continuing and we've said fundamentally in agreement with observers who saw PC market growth in the high teens to 20 percent range," he said.

Intel noted the PC market it supplies is expected to get a boost in the second half from shipment of Microsoft Corp's Windows NT 4.0 upgrade and from "the usual strong consumer buying season during Q4 and the holiday."
